name: (2,6-diphenyl-4H-pyran-4-yl)(diphenyl)phosphane oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2794

name: (2,6-diphenyl-4H-pyran-4-yl)(diphenyl)phosphane oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2794
Reason: The basic unit for the target compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The presence of multiple phenyl groups will tend to significantly increase the melting point because of the increased pi-pi stacking interactions and London dispersion forces due to the larger surface area and number of electrons. The phosphane oxide group is a highly polar functional group, which will introduce additional dipole-dipole interactions, further raising the melting point. - Phenyl group: +40 each (due to pi-pi stacking and increased dispersion forces). - Phosphane oxide group: +25 (due to dipole-dipole interactions). The compound has four phenyl groups attached, leading to an additive effect. Therefore, the prediction for the melting point would be: 5.5 (basic benzene unit) + 4 * 40 (four phenyl groups) + 25 (phosphane oxide group).

name: (2,6-diphenyl-4H-pyran-4-yl)(diphenyl)phosphane oxide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2794
Reason: The basic unit for the target compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The presence of multiple phenyl groups will significantly increase the melting point due to increased pi-pi stacking interactions and London dispersion forces from the larger surface area and number of electrons. The phosphane oxide group adds polarity and creates more dipole-dipole interactions, which should also raise the melting point. However, the initial prediction overestimates the contribution of each phenyl group. Considering that the molecule also requires geometric accommodation for these bulky groups, which could affect the crystal packing and thus, the melting point, we will slightly adjust the value added by each phenyl group and also scrutinize the addition due to the phosphane oxide group. - Adjusted Phenyl group: +30 each (accounting for pi-pi stacking and London forces) - Phosphane oxide group: +20 (considering dipole-dipole and potential steric effects that might not raise the melting point as initially predicted). The compound has four phenyl groups attached, leading to an additive effect. Therefore, the revised prediction for the melting point would be: 5.5 (basic benzene unit) + 4 * 30 (four phenyl groups) + 20 (phosphane oxide group).
